message.content: This question requires knowledge of the process of boiling water. When heat is applied to a pot of cold water, it gradually increases in temperature. As the temperature rises, tiny air bubbles start forming at the bottom of the pot and rise to the surface. These bubbles indicate that the water has reached its boiling point, where it starts to convert into steam. Option (B) is incorrect because the temperature of the food has no relation to the boiling point of water. Option (C) is incorrect because warm water does not necessarily mean it has reached its boiling point. Option (D) is irrelevant because it pertains to the addition of salt, not the boiling point of water.

This question requires basic knowledge about the boiling point of water. When heat is applied to a pot of cold water, it will gradually increase in temperature. As it reaches its boiling point, bubbles will start to form and rise to the surface. This is because the heat causes the water to evaporate and form water vapor bubbles. Option (B) is incorrect because the question is asking about the boiling point, not the state of the food. Option (C) is incorrect because the question is asking about the boiling point, not just the temperature of the water. Option (D) is unrelated to the boiling point of water as it refers to adding salt, which can affect the boiling point but is not necessary to reach it.

This question relates to the process of water heating and reaching its boiling point. When heat is applied to a pot of cold water, it gradually heats up. As the temperature rises, eventually it reaches the boiling point, which is 100 degrees Celsius or 212 degrees Fahrenheit. The boiling point is reached when bubbles are seen forming and rising to the surface of the water. Option (B) is incorrect because it is unrelated to the boiling point of water. Option (C) is also incorrect because water can be warm without reaching its boiling point. Option (D) is unrelated to the boiling point, as adding salt to water does not affect its boiling point.
